Mexico's "Ley Transparencia" Repealed In the Name of Security?A few hours ago, the "Ley Federal de Transparencia y Acceso a la Informaci√≥n Gubernamental" (Federal Law of Transparency and Access to Governmental Information), the first law passed by the government of Mexican President Enrique Pe√±a Nieto was repealed.In addition to providing the means for people to request information, the law created an authority to respond to these requests. This body was criticized for its lack of independence from government, and the Mexican president's right to appoint three members of the nine-person board.According to Article 68 of the Mexican Constitution, bills must be published for a period of 30 days before a president can sign them into law. However, in the case of this transparency law, no public consultation period took place, despite pressure from civil society.The "Ley Transparencia" was to take effect in 2014, but now this law ‚Äì which only recently passed in April 2013 ‚Äì has been repealed. A new transparency law was approved in the lower house of congress by an overwhelming majority on September 18, 2013.This new proposal, which could become the new law, includes a number of key differences:* In order to maintain a balance between the right to access information and the right to privacy, information about private individuals (i.e. public officials) must not be released without express consent.* The president will now have the authority to appoint all nine members to the board responsible for overseeing access to information.* Making public officials provide information on their income, assets and potential conflicts of interest becomes optional, at the discretion of the President.* The new law would not grant full access to information about government contracts, including the details of the bidding process and the terms of the contract.* The new law would not apply to private bodies contracted by the government.
